snippet: Damage to growth, employment and interest rates has already been extensive, economists say, even without a debt default and a continuation of the government shutdown.
abstract: Economists estimate that gridlock in Congress has already cost United States well into the billions, even as government shutdown and threat of default come to end; say damage to growth, employment and interest rates has already been extensive, and complete accounting could take months once government reopens and Treasury resumes adding to country's debt; total will continue to grow, partly because of uncertainty about whether lawmakers might reach another deadlock in early 2014.

byline.original: By ANNIE LOWREY, NATHANIEL POPPER and NELSON D. SCHWARTZ
byline.contributor: Annie Lowrey reported from Washington and Nathaniel Popper and Nelson D. Schwartz from New York.

lead_paragraph: Damage to growth, employment and interest rates has already been extensive, economists say, even without a debt default and a continuation of the government shutdown.

headline.main: Gridlock Has Cost U.S. Billions, and the Meter Is Still Running
headline.print_headline: Gridlock Has Cost U.S. Billions, and the Meter Is Still Running
